column1: Mahomes is Curry. Tannehill is Beal, since both weren't that good in their early years but now are getting recognized. Brady is lebron because rangz and GOAT tier. Rodgers is giannis, Wisconsin connection and both are loyal to their franchise. Lamar Jackson is luka, both got the physical tools but both can be better at throwing and shooting, respectively. Deshaun Watson is harden, both are/ were disgruntled. Kirk cousins us Demarcus cousins (lol) both were better in their earlier days and now are a shell of their former selves. Baker is kemba because both have good leadership qualities and sometimes get overlooked by other guys and yet they still ball out. Derek carr is LMA since they been playing for ages it seems like. Allen is jokic. Wilson is Durant. Herbert is tatum since they are both young franchise players for their teams. Matt Ryan is westbrook both guys get tunnell vision.

> This is most blatant in the NFL when #1 drafts consistently get dropped into the worst team in the league (it being the worst team for a reason), then cannot develop and then get railroaded out of the league.  I think that's more that those guys just suck. NFL #1 picks are more likely to become all-stars than NBA #1 picks.   NFL #1 pick all-stars since 2000:   - All-stars (15): Kyler Murray, Myles Garrett, Jared Goff, Jameis Winston, Jadaveon Clowney, Eric Fisher, Andrew Luck, Cam Newton, Matt Stafford, Jake Long, Mario Williams, Alex Smith, Eli Manning, Carson Palmer, Mike Vick  - Non-all-stars (6): Joe Burrow, Baker Mayfield, Sam Bradford, Jamarcus Russell, David Carr, Courtney Brown  NBA #1 overall picks since 2000:   - All-stars (12): Ben Simmons, Karl Anthony Towns, Anthony Davis, Kyrie Irving, John Wall, Blake Griffin, Derrick Rose, Andrew Bogut, Dwight Howard, Lebron James, Yao Ming, Kenyon Martin  - Non-all-stars (9): Anthony Edwards, Zion Williamson, Deandre Ayton, Markelle Fultz, Andrew Wiggins, Anthony Bennett, Greg Oden, Andrea Bargnani, Kwame Brown  Zion seems like a pretty sure bet to become an all-star in the future, but I could say the same for Burrow.   > That's why the best NFL quarterbacks nowadays are mid-round picks and late round picks  Only 2 of them: Wilson and Brady. 4 if you wanna include "good not great" QBs like Kirk Cousins and Dak Prescott.   Meanwhile the 1st round QBs include: Patrick Mahomes, Aaron Rodgers, Deshaun Watson, Josh Allen, Lamar Jackson, Phillip Rivers, Ben Roethlisberger, Matt Ryan, Ryan Tannehill, Justin Herbert. That's already 10, not including any who were listed above as #1 overall picks.   Then you also have Drew Brees and Derek Carr as early 2nd rounders (ie, not midround picks).

>. Steph would have more attempts than most teams in the 80s they’d have no idea what to do with him.  They would have beat the shit out of him, grabbed onto him, knocked him the F out after he went up in the air.  Then you get hurt/tired.  I reccomend you look up how teams defended Michael Jordan.    "If Michael was at the point, we forced him left and doubled him. If he was on the left wing, we went immediately to a double team from the top. If he was on the right wing, we went to a slow double team. He could hurt you equally from either wing—hell, he could hurt you from the hot-dog stand—but we just wanted to vary the look. And if he was on the box, we doubled with a big guy. **The other rule was, any time he went by you, you had to nail him. If he was coming off a screen, nail him. We didn't want to be dirty—I know some people thought we were—but we had to make contact and be very physical.**"  https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_Rules  It gave Jordan Trouble.  It'd give any NBA player in the league right now trouble.  It'd give any NBA player in history trouble.  Jordan is so great because he did what he did in THAT atmosphere.  Jordan's stats aren't leagues above other NBA players today... but he's considered better because offense was harder back then. Want to know why teams don't employ "Jordan Rules" anymore to defend superstars like Steph Curry?  Because you'd immediately foul of a game, and all your players would get ejected, and given flagrant 2's for hard fouls.  Do you FINALLY understand that NBA basketball back then was different?  And thus you have to view the stats through different lenses?  I mean, lets try this.  Do you agree that in the NFL we should view Dan Marino's stats through a different lens than a guy like Matt Ryan?  Is Matt Ryan MASSIVELY better than John Elway or Joe Montana, because his passing yards and passing TDs is way higher?  Of course not.  They played in different ages of football with completely different rules.  It's the same with Bird and Curry... do you now agree?

Fair enough, I had a long day.  I think the GOAT case is much harder to make. IMO Brady got a lot of help from defenses & coaching but it's hard to deny seven rings. But the question wasn't #1, it's #1-3. If you're going by stats, Rodgers is clearly in the convo. If you're going by SB wins, there's only four QBs with three or more - Brady, Montana, Aikman, and Bradshaw. I'm assuming you're not going to give the nod to Troy or Terry, so it can't just be about Super Bowls. (Or maybe you do think it's all about Super Bowls, in which case we're not going to get anywhere.)  There's a bunch of dudes with two SBs but only a few have a real argument for being better than Rodgers - Peyton (who was clearly carried to his last win by the defense) and... Starr if you're generous on era adjustments & history of the game? Maybe Elway? Either way, clearly a conversation.  If "enough in the playoffs" means winning not just Super Bowls but winning playoff games, I mean, Rodgers is great in the playoffs despite some high-profile losses. He's #4 all time in playoff passer rating behind Starr, Kurt Warner, and Matt Ryan. Tons of memorable games (Dallas 2014 & 2016 definitely come to mind, as does Philly 2010 and the two wins from the last two years), an absolute shelacking of the 1 seed in 2010 en route to his only Super Bowl, and even in the losses he frequently played great (I'm thinking of the two losses to AZ in '09 and '15, the latter of which he took to overtime despite his top 5 receivers being out). Definitely some clunkers too but everyone has those.  Tangentially, I honestly think there's a pretty good case for Marino as better than Rodgers and a top 3, but he only appeared in one SB and he got creamed so I'm assuming he's not on your list.  At minimum, it's clear to me that Rodgers is in the conversation. As a Packers fan who's watched 90% of games since about 2007, it's a frustrating one because if a ball had bounced a slightly different way like three times the whole narrative might be completely different. But if's and but's etc.
yeah everyone craps on the falcons, not Matt Ryan

It's not about one player choking it's the collective team effort of Choking.   Like I find it hard to think that Matt Ryan choked in the Superbowl considering he threw the ball to only where Julio can make that catch. I think Matt actually finished that Superbowl with a 144.7 passing rating but it's the collective team effort of Choking i.e. Devonta Freeman missing chip block, Jake Matthews holding, and defense being completely worn out and Vic Beasley not not intercepting that pass in the end zone.   It's a a team effort.

> I never said Matt was 100% problem I overtly said I actually like Matt. I'm arguing his era overall for most part to Falcons fans represent failure. This is about image. Whether or not he deserve the blame and honestly he doesn't he personally has been amazing for the Falcons, but with all lack of success people get tired and want to start a new chapter. And Since he is the top guy most of blame by fault is going to Ryan now.  So, what you are saying is, that Matt is a scapegoat for idiotic, fairweather fans? I can get behind that.

Before anything else I'll ask.. Why is Michael Vick considered a better QB? It's not that black fans prefer him, they genuinely think he is worlds better than Matt Ryan and would have won at least one Superbowl(usually more) if he got the same supposed chances Ryan has. You are on a completely different train of thought than I am here, addressing Matt as a somewhat uninformed fan instead of going into it with an inherent bias.   And again, that's not legitimate criticism. Matt has done more than enough to win games in recent memory and if you think otherwise you either aren't watching or have an inherent bias against him. If we didn't have Matt Ryan this franchise would be in the literal dumpster, after Petrino ran out we were predicted to be a trash franchise for years to come, and yet we draft Matt and he immediately breathes life into the team and leads us toward a much brighter future.   It is beyond weird that you think Matt Ryan's time with the Falcons somehow represents failure when.. bro, do you even know our history? Bottom feeder franchise our entire existence with the occasional flash of talent(Grits Blitz, Primetime) or overperforming season('98 Superbowl fluke appearance), we get exciting for a few years with Vick, but still aren't actually good, and then Matt comes in and not long after we are a perennial contender. The Matt Ryan era is the most successful time our franchise has ever known, and the fact that you seem to genuinely think otherwise is embarrassing for me to read.

I just said dude has only lead Falcons to the playoffs 2 times in last 8 year and first line you said "What is the legit criticism?"  wtf..........   I never said Matt was 100% problem I overtly said I actually like Matt. I'm arguing his era overall for most part to Falcons fans represent failure. This is about image. Whether or not he deserve the blame and honestly he doesn't he personally has been amazing for the Falcons, but with all lack of success people get tired and want to start a new chapter. And Since he is the top guy most of blame by fault is going to Ryan now.   As far as Drew Brees he still has a better playoff appearance ratio then Matt. And the fact he actually won a super bowl means a lot. Again this about image.  Dude won Superbowl after Katrina that had mean a lot for N.O. If Matt won yes that might have change a lot of his perception to have that parade in Atlanta.   My point its not because he's white that idea of even thinking is stupid, It's because he's not married to Success. His highs have been amazing but of his years as the guy has been so and so to just bad.

What is the legit criticism? Name one season where stats and tape back up what you're saying. You say I'm arguing with emotion and yet you insist Matt Ryan is somehow the problem? Football isn't basketball lmao, one player doesn't automatically win you games, I don't care who it is. You think Tom Brady wins 7 Superbowls with an average coach and roster? Drew Brees is considered a top 5 all time QB by many and only won a single Superbowl(and even that one has a bit of a red mark thanks to Bountygate), and missed the playoffs more times than he made it. Is he overrated trash as well?

And the fact that you think Matt Ryan is the issue proves my point. Ryan put up 28 points in that Superbowl, trusted his OC, and the team let him down. He put them in field goal position to seal the game and then his RB failed him, and then his LT failed him. Not to mention they actually almost went back to the NFC title game the next season if Julio would've just caught the ball, but apparently you didn't actually watch them play that season.

Theres a reason why everyone with Hawks flair is coming in and saying “no, Absolutely not”. The Falcons are a historically bad team, many would even say a historically cursed team. The last time they made the super bowl was 98, and they have no rings. You probably can’t name a single player on that 98 team besides the kicker.   2016 brought not just team success, but dazzling team success. Matt Ryan wins MVP. Their offense is historically great. They blow out Aaron Rodgers in the NFCCG to make the super bowl.   But every Falcons fan is still in here saying that there’s NO WAY that the season was worth it. The most successful season in franchise history by far, wasn’t worth it, and they would trade it all to have just missed the playoffs again.

Brady does literally everything imaginable to stave off aging, shit is a little creepy looking to me at this point tbh.  For comparison, both Rodgers and Matt Ryan also reportedly follow pretty strict diets/training regimens, but they've both cosmetically aged like normal living human beings.  So Brady is obviously some sort of weird outlier, but comparing him to Blanda is looking for the absolute polar opposite.  Here's a nice quite from Blanda on his secret to defying father time:   "After last year people came up to me and said, 'George, how do you do it? What's your secret?  Word got out that I had a special diet, that I didn't drink or smoke. One 'insider' said that I was taking hormones, and that was why I was able to play so many games at my ripe old age. Well, there is no secret. My special diet consists of the same things I've been eating ever since I grew up: steak and potatoes and green vegetables. I smoke and I drink. The worst five years of my 21 as a pro were the five when I didn't smoke at all. Now I've gone back to cigarettes, a pack or two a day, although I don't inhale them. As for alcohol, I enjoy bourbon -- it's part of my University of Kentucky background -- but I don't guzzle it down like water. I sip it, and I limit myself to two or three drinks. You may see old George Blanda acting stupid, but you won't see him acting drunk!"

Being the best for one season doesn't make you a superstar, Rich Gannon won MVP and he wasn't a superstar. Russell Wilson has never won an MVP but he's still a superstar player. The term superstar isn't a sports term in origin, which is why it is not a fully merit-based term. A superstar is someone of wide fame who is also successful. They don't necessarily have to be the best, but sometimes they are. Mike Vick is a superstar because he was an entertaining and unique player, he was always amongst the highest paid jerseys, he put the Atlanta Falcons in the spotlight, he had many many young kids wanting to be like him, and even had his own shoe. Matt Ryan just isn't that type of guy, his personality type and playstyle just isn't someone that a city like Atlanta will embrace unlike Trae Young who is a superstar in Atlanta. There were many people who were wanting to draft Matt Ryan's replacement this year

Superstar doesn't mean best player. A superstar is more of marking ability than it is talent (its really a combination of the two but marketing ability matters a bit more). Matt Ryan is a more talented QB than Mike Vick, but he isn't going to be seen as a superstar like Mike Vick was. There's a reason Matt Ryan is constantly disrespected despite being a good QB.
